item.title: Midpoint Formula in a Java method
item.dc:creator: @wildskiller wildskiller
item.description:
@wildskiller wrote:

[quote=“tyb97, post:13, topic:458066”][quote author=wildskiller link=topic=560989.msg4099093#msg4099093 date=1347226497]

I assume you are in geometry?

How exactly do you get to do Java in geometry? I wish I went to your school :,(

I wish we did lol, I just got really bored doing this stupid stuff and made this :3

Well, what are you trying to do? I’m thinking coordinate planes
[/quote]
Bascially, the questions are laid out like so:

Find the midpoint between these two points:
E (-3, 5), F (2, -5)

Etc. etc.[/quote]

I’m terrible with finding the rule of things and turning it into a formula for Java. It’s what I need most.

I’m gonna try to do this.

Read full topic

item.description:
@tyb97 wrote:

The Wanderer:

My geometry teacher wouldn’t let us use calculators. We had to knows perfect squares up to 25 and whatnot. If you have a droid phone you could make this a simple app for your phone and ask if you could use your phone for a calculator.

We “have too” use the calculator she says to use, or she writes you up.

item.source: Midpoint Formula in a Java method

item.title: Midpoint Formula in a Java method
item.dc:creator: @tyb97 tyb97
item.description:
@tyb97 wrote:

Yes, this isn’t complex in any way, nor does it handle anything advanced. Just a quick way to check your answers, and I want to contribute it.

import java.util.Scanner;


public class Math {

	
	static Scanner scanner = new Scanner(System.in);

	public static void main(String[] args) {
		calculate();
	}
	
	private static void calculate() {
		double answerX, answerY, x1, x2, y1, y2;
		
		System.out.print("X1:");
		x1 = scanner.nextDouble();
		System.out.print("\nX2:");
		x2 = scanner.nextDouble();
		System.out.print("\nY1:");
		y1 = scanner.nextDouble();
		System.out.print("\nY2:");
		y2 = scanner.nextDouble();
		
		answerX = (x1 + x2) / 2;
		answerY = (y1 + y2) / 2;
		
		System.out.println("(" + answerX + ", " + answerY + ")");
	}

}

Enjoy.

Read full topic
item.source: Midpoint Formula in a Java method
